#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=Artefacts returned to Italy in 2008 after Italian investigations into illicit trading .
#Text=In September 1995 , the Italian Carabinieri , in conjunction with Swiss police , raided Italian antiquities dealer Giacomo Medici ’ s storerooms in Geneva Freeport .

#Text=The raids on Medici ’ s storerooms were part of a wide-ranging investigation into the antiquities trade out of Italy , and more raids followed in 2001 on US dealer Robert Hecht ’ s apartment in Paris and in 2002 and 2005 on Italian dealer Gianfranco Becchina ’ s premises in Basel .

#Text=The evidence collected during the course of the Italian investigation caused several US art museums to return material to Italy , including the Cleveland Museum of Art.As long ago as 1973 , Cleveland ’ s then-curator of ancient art John Cooney had expressed his belief that ninety-five percent of material in the United States had been ‘ smuggled in ’ , adding that even for ‘ hot ’ objects , he was only concerned to verify their legal entry into the United States , identifying Switzerland as a point of transit .

#Text=Cooney described Hecht as ‘ always meticulous and upright ’ , with ‘ one of the best eyes in the business ’ , adding that he never asked Hecht for documents of provenance—he thought it would be ridiculous .
#Text=On 19 November 2008 , the Cleveland Museum and the Italian Ministry of Culture announced in a joint press release that the museum had agreed to return fourteen antiquities to Italy .

#Text=For its part , Italy agreed to loan Cleveland a similar number of pieces of equivalent quality , and to organize a close association between Cleveland and an Italian institution for future collaborations .
#Text=The museum director Timothy Rub was quoted as saying that the agreement absolved the museum of any intentional wrongdoing .
#Text=He refused to name any dealers involved in the acquisitions , though details had already been released by Suzan Mazur .

#Text=The two parties also agreed to form a joint scientific commission to research the provenance of the Apollo Sauroktonos , and also of a Roman chariot attachment depicting Victory with Cornucopia .
#Text=The pieces returned were : Red-figure duck askos , Italy , probably Chiusi ( ancient Clusium ) , Etruscan , fourth-century BC , c 350 BC .
#Text=Purchase .
#Text=Sicilian plastic vase in the form of a pig , Sicily , provincial Greece , fifth century BC , c 425 BC .
#Text=Gift of Leo Mildenberg .
#Text=Processional Cross , Italian , fourteenth-century AD .
#Text=( This piece had been stolen from an Italian church after World War Two , and its return was not connected to the investigations into Medici , Becchina , and Hecht ) .
#Text=Donkey-head rhyton , Greece , fifth century BC , c 475 BC .
#Text=Purchase .
#Text=Apulian or Campanian red-figure lid with bowl , South Italy , Apulia , fourth century BC .
#Text=Gift of Jonathan P Rosen .
#Text=Apulian Gnathia Flat-Bodied Epichysis , Italy , Middle Gnathia , fourth century BC , c 340-320 BC .
#Text=Gift of Jonathan P Rosen .
#Text=Apulian Gnathia round-bellied epichysis , Italy , Middle Gnathia , fourth century BC , c 340–320 BC .
#Text=Gift of Jonathan P Rosen .
#Text=Apulian Gnathia lekythos , Italy , Middle Gnathia , fourth century BC , c 340–330 BC .
#Text=Gift of Jonathan P Rosen .
#Text=Campanian red-figure acorn lekythos , South Italy , Campania , fourth century BC , c 350–320 BC .
#Text=Gift of Jonathan P Rosen .
#Text=Campanian bird askos , South Italy , northern Campania , late fourth–early third century BC , c 310–280 BC .
#Text=Gift of Mr and Mrs LA Fleischman .
#Text=Apulian volute-krater , Darius Painter ( Italian ) , c 330 BC .
#Text=Purchase .
#Text=Warrior , Sardinia , ninth–eighth century BC .
#Text=Purchase .
#Text=Column krater , Greece , late Early Corinthian–early Middle Corinthian , c 600–590 BC .

#Text=Gift of E Almagia and C Keep in honour of Arielle P Kozloff .
